content.label: Essential Question in {{STATE_NAME}}
content.question:
What could go wrong with your savings and investments?

And how can you protect yourself from financial risks? in {{STATE_NAME}}

objectives.description: Identify different types of financial risks: market risk, financial risk, inflation risk, and fraud risk.
Understand how these risks can affect your savings and investments over time.
Describe risk tolerance and how it varies among individuals based on goals and circumstances.
Use diversification and asset allocation strategies to manage and reduce financial risks.

terms.definition: The possibility of losses due to factors affecting the overall financial markets‚Äîrecessions, global events, policy changes.
terms.example: Tech stocks fell 30% during a market downturn‚Äîaffecting all investors in that sector

terms.definition: Risk related to a specific company's ability to manage debt and meet its financial obligations.
terms.example: A company goes bankrupt and can't repay bondholders‚Äîinvestors lose money

terms.definition: The risk that your money's purchasing power decreases over time as prices rise‚Äîthe "silent thief."
terms.example: $10,000 earning 1% while inflation is 3% = losing 2% buying power yearly

terms.definition: The danger of losing money to scams, deceptive practices, or fraudulent investment schemes.
terms.example: "Guaranteed 20% returns with no risk" = almost always a scam!

content.headerTitle: Market Risk: When Markets Move Against You

scenario.name: Anna's Tech Stock Investment in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Anna invested $5,000 in a technology company's stock, believing in the industry's growth potential.
When a new competitor entered the market and tech stocks generally declined, her investment dropped to $4,200‚Äîa loss of $800.
Key Lesson: Market-wide factors (recessions, political events, industry shifts) can affect individual investments‚Äîeven good companies can lose value when the whole market drops.

outcomes.label: Protection Strategy in {{STATE_NAME}}
outcomes.detail: Don't put all in one sector in {{STATE_NAME}}

leftPanel.title: Financial Risk: Company Troubles
paragraphs: Sam's Story: He purchased $3,000 in corporate bonds from a promising startup. The company struggled with cash flow and couldn't repay bondholders.
Result: Sam lost a significant portion of his investment.
Lesson: Always evaluate a company's financial stability before investing. Strong finances = lower financial risk.

highlightBox.text: � Check credit ratings and financial statements before buying bonds!

layoutData.title: How Much Risk Can YOU Handle?
paragraphs: Risk tolerance is your personal comfort level with potential fluctuations in your investments. It's influenced by your goals, timeline, personality, and financial situation.
bulletPoints: Conservative: Prefers stability. Uncomfortable with significant fluctuations. Prioritizes protecting what you have.
Moderate: Can tolerate some ups and downs. Seeks balance between growth and protection.
Aggressive: Comfortable with substantial fluctuations. Focuses on maximum growth potential over time.
Key factors: Your age, time horizon, financial goals, income stability, and emotional response to losses.

keyPoint.text: üéØ Knowing your risk tolerance helps you choose investments you can stick with through market ups and downs!

leftPanel.title: Don't Put All Your Eggs in One Basket
paragraphs: Diversification means spreading your money across different types of investments to reduce risk.
Different assets respond differently to economic events. When one investment goes down, others might go up‚Äîsmoothing out your overall returns.
The Power: If all your money is in one stock and it tanks, you could lose everything. But if you're spread across 20 investments, one failure won't devastate you.

highlightBox.text: ü•ö Diversification is one of the few "free lunches" in investing‚Äîreduce risk without sacrificing returns!

leftPanel.title: Balancing Risk and Return
paragraphs: Asset allocation is how you divide your investments among different asset categories based on your risk tolerance, time horizon, and goals.
Stocks: Higher risk, higher potential return. Best for long-term growth.
Bonds: Moderate risk, moderate return. Provides income and stability.
Cash/Equivalents: Lower risk, lower return. Safe but doesn't grow much.

highlightBox.text: ‚öñÔ∏è Your ideal mix depends on when you need the money and how much volatility you can handle!

content.headerTitle: Real-World Example: The Danger of No Diversification

scenario.name: Jamie's Single-Stock Disaster in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Jamie loved a particular tech company and invested their entire $20,000 savings in that one stock.
When the company faced unexpected competition and regulatory issues, the stock dropped 70%. Jamie's $20,000 became $6,000.
Lesson: No matter how much you believe in a company, putting all your money in one place is extremely risky. Jamie could have protected themselves with diversification.

content.headerTitle: Real-World Example: The Power of Diversification

scenario.name: Morgan's Diversified Portfolio in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Morgan invested the same $20,000 but spread it across an index fund covering 500 companies.
When that same tech company crashed, Morgan's portfolio only dropped about 15% because the loss was just a small part of the total.
Better yet: While tech struggled, Morgan's healthcare and consumer goods stocks actually went UP, partially offsetting the losses. Their portfolio recovered within a year.
